title: Crypto regulation: UK must end  hyped-up claims for stablecoins
text:
The UK is preparing to lasso the humbled crypto bull, with a sweeping new regulatory regime.

Stablecoins, typically pegged at one dollar, deserve particular focus. These have often been treated as a safer digital asset. Doubts over that definition have deepened with the collapse of a $9bn deal between Bob Diamond's Spac and Circle, which operates the second largest stablecoin, USD Coin.

Circle has positioned USDC as the transparent option in a $140bn market where questions over the reserves backing the tokens in circulation have been rife. Its public filings reveal a breakdown of its $44bn of holdings in cash and Treasuries.

Stablecoins can be more than just an on-ramp to the crypto casino, claims Circle. Donors used USDC to send aid to Venezuelans. Visa and Mastercard have trialled it as a means to settle transactions. In happier times, FTX said it paid a large proportion of its team in USDC.

But fintechs such as Wise and Remitly have already slashed the cost of cross-border remittances, without the need for a synthetic dollar. And since stablecoins are primarily used for cryptocurrency trading, their operators' fortunes depend heavily upon this cowboy market. The value of USDC in circulation has contracted from more than $55bn in June to $43bn today following FTX's collapse.

Other stablecoins have signally failed to live up to their name. Analysts at JPMorgan found that the four largest coins routinely broke the buck, trading below par 25-40 per cent of the time between April and July 2021. This May, the $65bn juggernaut of Tether lost its $1 peg, briefly falling as low as 95.11 cents after the collapse of TerraUSD, an $18bn stablecoin which relied on algorithms to keep it steady.

The upshot is that in any regulated form, stablecoins would have to live up to their name or rebrand under a banner that reflects their risks. The first requirement implies hefty reserves that would raise costs prohibitively. The second simply requires marketing ingenuity. Block bunce? Faux fiat? Suggestions on a post card to the Financial Conduct Authority.
